captions.text:
As a world-famous video game critic with an 
attractive accent, thick head of glorious hair,

enormous barrel chest, and who has recently 
gotten over several self-esteem issues,

people often ask me about my methods. Well, first, 
figure out how to totally delude yourself. &quot;No,

no, Yahtzee. Your game reviewing methods.&quot; Oh. 
&quot;Do you prepare before you start playing? Do

you take notes?&quot; Take notes? Ooh, look at me 
with my little notepad, licking my pencil,

wearing my hat with the card that says &#39;press&#39; on 
it, and staying completely sober like a fucking

tryhard. No. I go with my gut. I play games 
trying to push all thoughts of critique out

of my mind and only afterwards ask myself, &quot;Was 
I enjoying that?&quot; And when I have an answer,

I think back and interrogate that feeling. Why was 
I enjoying it? Was it fun to play or was it the

rubbing alcohol? So, going through that process, 
Eternal Strands is a game I was enjoying. And it

couldn&#39;t have been rubbing alcohol &#39;cos my doctor 
says I need to lay off while we see if my body&#39;s

rejecting the donated liver, so there must have 
been something I liked about it. Let&#39;s see if

we can figure out what that was together. First 
thing&#39;s first: Was it the title? No, it fucking

sucks. Doesn&#39;t tell you shit. Sounds like what a 
romance novelist would name a hairdresser&#39;s shop.

Second thing&#39;s second: Is it the visual 
design? Nope. I gather this is a debut game,

for the studio if not the individuals involved, 
and it uses the visual style known as &quot;this is

the developer&#39;s first game.png.&quot; Generic 
fantasy world with heavy World of Warcraft

vibes—big environments, slightly quirky 
architecture, nice, inoffensive color scheme,

character portraits straight from somebody&#39;s 
college game design degree art portfolio.

The plot is we are Brynn, generic fantasy 
adventurer protagonist person noteworthy only

for her apparent aversion to vowels, we join 
a caravan of magical scientists investigating

a mysterious land that has been sealed off for 
decades after a magical disaster, and somehow,

shit gets fucky, and we get stuck inside the 
barrier. &quot;So was it the characters you liked,

Yahtz?&quot; Not really. It&#39;s nice to have a whole 
support team chipping in on our missions Metal

Gear Solid-style, but for that to work, the 
support team can&#39;t be a bunch of big, boring

bastards. They&#39;re a diverse group of terribly 
civilized fantasy people who are a bit quirky

but all very professional and understanding 
and nice and get along without any of that

drama and interpersonal conflict that makes a 
cast the slightest bit actually interesting.

And they&#39;ve all got a bad case of &quot;need to 
reestablish my personality with my every

cocking line of dialogue&quot;-itis. &quot;Well, speaking 
as the archivist daughter of an Elven archmage

rebelling against their family-&quot; Yeah, don&#39;t 
pad your timesheet, dialogue writer; sometimes,

a simple &quot;go kill that dragon&quot; is all you need. 
So, by process of elimination, was it the gameplay

you like, Yahtzee? What kind of game is it? 
Well, in brief, it&#39;s a gear grinder—ah, ah,

ah! Don&#39;t run away just yet. It&#39;s a gear grinder 
with an extraction element—no, look, stay here;

let me finish. It&#39;s no use, I locked all the 
fucking doors. The format is you have a base

camp and mount expeditions to one of several 
open-ended areas to fight the local monsters,

collect crafting materials, and maybe pursue a 
story objective or two if you&#39;re a good little

tryhard. &quot;Ah, then perhaps &#39;twas the combat 
system that worked your shaft, Yahtz?&quot; No,

enemy variety&#39;s not up to much—you chip away at 
the spongey health bars of wolves, wasps, and

robots in a manner about as cathartic as whittling 
a tent peg. There&#39;s this elemental damage system

where you can both freeze things and light stuff 
on fire, but all I usually did was encase every

single enemy in the starting ice wall power and 
then chip away at my leisure. And then there was

even less enemy variety &#39;cos I was attacking 
nothing but giant, stationary, blue popsicles.

Once you&#39;ve filled your backpack&#39;s seven 
condom packets&#39; worth of inventory space,

you head back to camp to see if there&#39;s anything 
new you can craft. &quot;Well, I assume it wasn&#39;t the

crafting you liked, Yahtz. Yahtz. It wasn&#39;t 
the fucking crafting. Okay...SHUT THE FUCK UP,

YAHTZ.&quot; The thing is, and I don&#39;t think it&#39;s 
the first game to do this, the recipes are

completely unspecific. It just says &quot;a stone.&quot; &quot;A 
leather.&quot; Any leather. So you don&#39;t have to hang

around area A, grinding up a very specific kind 
of wasp foreskin. You can substitute with wolf

scrotums if that&#39;s all you&#39;ve got kicking around, 
and it&#39;ll make perfectly functional underpants,

just with different stats. So as long 
as I was picking up decent materials,

I could relax about psychotically loading up on 
every leaf, stick, and disembodied nether region

available on the off-chance they&#39;d be needed; I 
could focus on exploring the pretty environment,

filling out the map, skipping through 
the meadows, setting fire to things,

and after I&#39;m loaded up on bullshit and done a 
quest objective or two, I might say to myself,

&quot;All right, I&#39;ve done good work, maybe I&#39;ll 
reward myself with a quick giant robot fight.

The way I look over a shopping cart full of 
vegetables and healthy protein and think, &quot;Yes,

I have done some excellent grown-up shopping. Time 
to fill all the remaining space with jam donuts.&quot;

Oh, yes, I forgot to mention there&#39;s giant monster 
fights, and those are where it gets interesting.

In contrast to the standard combat that&#39;s like 
using a hammer to break open gobstoppers that

won&#39;t stop rolling off the kitchen counter, 
the giant monsters are Shadow of the Colossus,

crawl around a big bastard&#39;s armpits, knifing 
his sensitive areas affairs, but they aren&#39;t so

big as to require a massive commitment. They&#39;re 
the six-piece McNugget boxes to Shadow of the

Colossus&#39; artfully crafted coq au vin, but well 
implemented for all that. You kill them once to

learn a new spell, then upgrade that spell by 
killing them again in a specific way. &quot;Hey,

wait a second, Yahtz. Expeditions from base 
camp? Collecting crafting materials? Crawling

all over a giant monster&#39;s pubes, trying to 
kill it in highly specific ways? Isn&#39;t this

just Monster Hunter?&quot; You know what, if 
it helps get things in perspective, yes,

it&#39;s Fisher Price Monster Hunter. It&#39;s the theme 
park version of Monster Hunter where you can pick

a fight with a huge bastard without feeling 
like you need to commit to chasing it through

the undergrowth for an hour and a half after you 
make its poor little toesy-woesies hurt too much.

As I said, Eternal Strands comes from a debut 
studio, and that certainly comes across. The

generic art and setting, the combination of 
gameplay elements cribbed from the creators&#39;

favorite classic games; all of this yells &quot;first 
game foot in the door.&quot; But there&#39;s enough unique

about the combination to make it worth a look. 
Much more so in the first half when there&#39;s

still a sense of exploration and discovery; in 
the second half, basically all the story quests

come down to &quot;go to place you&#39;ve already been 
like three times and randomly piss about until

whatever piece of paper you&#39;re currently 
looking for is close enough to make the

objective marker pop up.&quot; Still, I would call 
Eternal Strands a &quot;very solid starting point.&quot;

You know how Pablo Picasso started out doing 
normal, boring, realistic portraits of people,

and then once he&#39;d demonstrated understanding 
of the rules, he could proceed to break them and

do all his weird, career-defining stuff? That&#39;s 
what Eternal Strands is. It&#39;s Picasso&#39;s boring,

early stuff. A perfectly well-put-together 
demonstration that the developers understand

the principles. Now, I want to see them make 
some motherfucking art. Make a game about a lady

with both ears on the same side of her head 
and a 1955 Morris Minor instead of an arse.
